title: Wednesday, 15th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Morning, then! Welcome. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the markets and the live.

BE11:03am

BE11:03am

Absolutely not a coup.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

You can always tell it's not a coup because there's a guy in fatigues on telly who's explaining that the army will "pacify a degenerating, social, and economic situation."

BE11:03am

We wish to make it abundantly clear that this is not a military takeover of government.

BE11:03am

As soon as we have accomplished our mission we expect that the situation will return to normalcy.

11:03 am
BE11:04am

Normalcy is of course a relative term in Zim.

NH11:04am

Morning all

BE11:04am

And morning, Neil. Good of you to join us again.

11:04 am
BE11:05am

Get your Zim updates here, from Joseph Cotterill: https://www.ft.com...-ab18-7a9fb7d6163e

NH11:05am

Talking of revolutionary groups taking over media organisations

NH11:05am

has it also happened closer to home?

11:05 am
BE11:05am

........... go on.

NH11:05am

how do you add a pic?

BE11:06am

Just drop a jpg link in and the system will process. We've the most advanced technology 2005 can provide.

11:06 am
NH11:06am

let me try

NH11:06am

hang on

BE11:07am

............... I'm braced here. Braced and ready.

11:07 am

Rubbish

NH11:07am

BE11:07am

http://www.bbc.co....s/blogs/the_papers

first front page

THE BREXIT MUTINEERS

BE11:08am

Former AV'er Josepth Cotterill

NH11:09am

following the situation in Zim for us

NH11:09am

A bit

NH11:10am

I believe some of the big traders

sell for some of the state-backed companies

NH11:10am

get the impression its chrome

NH11:10am

maganese

11:11 am

And by memory, both Barclays and Old Mut had some exposure but I think they've both exited.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 178.82, down 1.88 (-1.04%), High: 180.35, Low: 178.70, Volume: 6.49m
Old Mutual PLC (OML:LSE): Last: 188.00, down 0.9 (-0.48%), High: 189.50, Low: 187.90, Volume: 1.30m

Are they stocks with Zim exposure?

BE11:12am

None spring to mind. Fastjet maybe? In the sense that they have a flight that's probably only really getting booked in one direction right now.

Fastjet PLC (FJET:LSE): Last: 20.50, down 0.25 (-1.20%), Volume: 5.56k
11:13 am
BE11:13am

Anyway, we should probably shunt on to things that are actually moving.

NH11:13am

Wasn't Big Dave Lenigas in Zim

BE11:13am

Oh, probably.

11:13 am
NH11:13am

via Lonrho

NH11:13am

or whatever it became

NH11:13am

I hear big Dave is down under

11:13 am
NH11:14am

where the market for lithium, cobalt, nickel, gold stocks

NH11:14am

is very very hot

NH11:14am

But we digress

11:14 am
NH11:14am

Shall we move on to more substantive issues

undefined
BE11:15am

So, in terms of movers ..... TalkTalk's still TalkTalk.

11:15 am
NH11:15am

yes

NH11:15am

saw a few headlines

NH11:15am

Charles Dunstone having to invest more

11:15 am
NH11:15am

to improve the offering

BE11:15am

And the change of management hasn't yet changed the underlying company, which is still an absolute nightmare to make sense of.

BE11:16am

So today we get a light warning on FY2018

11:16 am
NH11:16am

I feel not enough was made of the poor job the former CEO did

BE11:17am

Well ....... you can argue that TalkTalk was always a bit stuck strategically ......

NH11:17am

true

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Not enough scale to be a price setter, not enough cash to invest in anything.

BE11:18am

Previous CEO went for quad play by the very cheapest routes possible .....

BE11:18am

As in, an MVNO and those terrible TV boxes that never worked.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Dunstone's come in and is unwinding a lot of this. Unsurprisingly, the numbers are an absolute nightmare as a result.

BE11:19am

So, headline H1 EBITDA looks to have missed consensus .....

BE11:20am

... but there's a £31m exceptional for closing mobile.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

(Incidentally: £31m!)

NH11:20am

wow

BE11:20am

Which is offset a bit by a £7m loss removed from the EBITDA

11:20 am
NH11:20am

that sounds alot

NH11:21am

(I love the Wiswatersrand. Clear load of nonsense but highly entertaining)

BE11:21am

I guess they paid upfront for a lot of leased time on the network and have had to write it off? Not sure.

11:21 am
NH11:21am

All in all then

NH11:21am

Dunstone doing a bit of kitchen sinking

NH11:21am

reset the base etc

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Well, yeah, maybe. There's a bunch of other one-offs for property and network costs, but we're used to those.

NH11:22am

some grey?

BE11:22am

Sure. One moment.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Hang on, computer's just seized up. Will get there eventually.

NH11:24am

OK

BE11:24am

Here's Citi.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

...........TalkTalk reported 1H FY18 results with adjusted EBITDA at £95m or
£88m including losses from its MVNO as previously (Citi: £100m; company
consensus: £95m). Post exceptionals, EBITDA was only £29m, below our estimate
of £95m, and statutory revenue at £856m, down 5% yoy, was also below our
estimate of £866m. Management downgraded its EBITDA guidance to the lower
end of its previous £270m-£300m range, however this now excludes MVNO costs
for the year which we'd expect to be £10-15m. Hence we see the equivalent new
guidance as around £255-260m, a mid-point to mid-point cut of c.10%. The
company reported headline FCF at £18m and cash outflow for the FY17 final
dividend of £47m but net debt rose £55m hoh to £837m. The company did not
repeat its previous guidance of FCF “improving yoy” in FY18.

BE11:24am

They're sellers.

BE11:25am

Better operational KPIs in 2Q — On net broadband adds were at +26k in 2Q
FY18 vs +20k in 1Q18. On net churn fell to 1.37% in 2Q18 vs 1.43% in 2Q17. Fibre
net adds were better +89k vs 72k in 1Q18 and TV net adds returned to a positive to
+24k vs loss of -5k last quarter.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Exceptionals to cover MVNO costs, reorganization and property — The
company is treating its MVNO operating losses (£7m in 1H) as exceptional since it
is intending to switch to a distributor model for mobile in 3Q. Including MVNO losses
the exceptional costs came to £66m include £20m for its management
reorganization, move to Soapworks in Salford, and other property rationalisation,
£31m on MVNO related asset write offs, decommissioning and onerous supplier
commitments and £8m for network transformation.

BE11:25am

And sorry about the duff formatting.

BE11:25am

mplications — Although there was some daylight shown in an improving core
revenue trend in 2Q (ex-carrier -1.4%) the cost of the turnaround is proving greater
than expected and the cut to the EBITDA outlook much more material than we had
forecast. The company has £222m in undrawn facilities and £56m in available cash
and we are surprised the board has declared an interim dividend at 2.5p.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

The point on the divi is an interesting one.

NH11:26am

it is

BE11:26am

A proper kitchen sinking by Dunstone would've seen that sacrificed for a new strategy of recovering market share and stuff.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Instead, he's gone for throwing a banana to the income types.

NH11:26am

so this is more of an en suite bathroom sinking

NH11:26am

than the kitchen variety

11:27 am
NH11:27am

I was just reading a funny profile of the former TalkTalk CEO Dido Harding who drinks hot water apparently because coffee makes her too hyper. How odd is that? I thought it was green tea that top execs drink instead of coffee. At least that's my experience.

NH11:27am

The 49-year-old, who drinks hot water as coffee makes her “too hyper”, will now step back from the City to pursue public service roles after Sir Charles Dunstone, TalkTalk founder, reasserted control. She says she has no interest in running another listed company.

NH11:27am

Public service

11:27 am
NH11:27am

It's good to give back

BE11:28am

I'm sure the nation will welcome her expertise, whatever it might be.

NH11:28am

Ms Harding, who later became a Conservative peer adopting the name Baroness Harding of Winscombe, studied philosophy, politics and economics at Oxford university, where she was an contemporary of David Cameron, and later earned an MBA from Harvard Business School. She is married to John Penrose, a Conservative MP.

She initially made her name in horseracing as the owner of Cool Dawn, which won the Cheltenham Gold Cup in 1998. That led to her joining the board of the Jockey Club and she attributes her career in business to the success of the “old horse”.

11:28 am
NH11:28am

Dear lord

NH11:28am

I can read no more

NH11:29am

what next

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Wonder if she's aiming for a job at Ofcom?

BE11:29am

Anyway.

NH11:29am

Teeth smile

BE11:30am

So, what's the story here?

NH11:31am

China slowdown fears it seems

11:30 am

NH11:31am

NH11:31am

has everyone worried

New homes sale fell at the fastest pace in three years I believe

NH11:32am

11:32 am
NH11:32am

Look I think China’s economy will probably slow as Xi Jinping pushes through his reforms

NH11:32am

But this isn’t going to be a recession

NH11:32am

That said commodity prices tend to decline in the run up to the year end and then will also have China’s battle against pollution over the winter.

11:32 am
NH11:32am

So it could be a tough couple of months for the miners.

NH11:33am

Overall I think this more about things going a bit risk off

NH11:33am

Hang on I have some grey

11:33 am

Thumbs up

NH11:33am

This is from Marex Spectron, one of the biggest brokers on the LME

NH11:33am

The timing and power in yesterday’s move lower suggestive of it being macro driven with a broad basket of commodities coming under distinct pressure and it is the continuing weakness in the stock markets overnight which suggests there is more downside to come over the next session or so. CTA sell programs are already apparent today across some of the metals, with key tech levels having been breached. Noticeably just COPPER and ALI are seeing good volume; Ali sees 4.1k lots trade by 8am, +81% on the 20-day avg.

11:33 am
NH11:34am

Crude oil is hovering close to yesterday's lows, which if broken, is likely to see sharp downside momentum build. The APIs showed a large crude build of 6.513m. After yesterday's sell-off in the evening session, which saw a near 6% move from high to low, Iron ore is relatively stable.

NH11:34am

So risk off

NH11:34am

actually I have a good note on this from Capital Economics

11:34 am
NH11:34am

Perhaps the most likely explanation, though, is worries about valuations. The credit spreads of US high-yield corporate bonds were around their lowest since the onset of the global financial crisis before their jump. And several major equity indices were at all-time, or multi-decade, highs before they slipped.

NH11:34am

We have previously argued that the equilibrium valuations of risky assets are much higher now than in the past due to a structural decline in interest rates. But this does not preclude some pull-back. Indeed, our forecast is for the S&P 500 to end the year a little below its current level.

However, we doubt that recent weakness will last. We forecast that the S&P 500 will be flat in 2018, while we project that stock markets in many other countries will rise a bit next year. Large declines in equities have usually occurred in the run-up to, or during, slowdowns in

NH11:35am

So a few people taking some chips off the table, which seems sensible

11:34 am
NH11:35am

as for the oil market

NH11:35am

preliminary US stocks data was out overnight

NH11:35am

suggest a big build over the past week

11:35 am
NH11:35am

that plus Tuesday's bearish IEA report - cutting demand forecasts for next year

NH11:35am

has brought a bit of sanity back to the oil market

NH11:36am

Right, this is from PVM

11:35 am
NH11:36am

Oil bulls have been left nursing a heavy hangover after the bearish lead from the IEA sent skittish buyers scurrying for the exits. Prices fell hard yesterday with Brent touching a low of $61.21/bbl before recovering to end the session 95 cts/bbl lower at $62.21/bbl. WTI briefly slipped below $55/bbl before finishing the day at $55.70/bbl for a loss of $1.06/bbl. It is worth nothing that this reversal in momentum comes only a week after both crude markers hit their highest level in more than two years. Such was the prevailing bullish sentiment that talk of $70/bbl oil started doing the rounds. Now though, this sanguinity appears to have been premature.

NH11:36am

In the meantime, yesterday’s slide is being compounded this morning by a fresh dose of price angst from an API report concerning US oil inventories. Crude stockpiles unexpectedly soared by 6.5 million bbls while gasoline stocks also registered a surprise build of 2.4 million bbls. A bigger-than-expected 2.5 million bbl fall in distillate inventories failed to lift sentiment. All of a sudden, it seems that positives are in short supply for market bulls

NH11:36am

That data comes out at 3.30pm if anyone is interested

11:36 am
NH11:36am

EIA weekly stocks report and widely followed by the oil market

NH11:36am

at least the paper traders in the oil market

BE11:03am

Picture to start, as is tradition.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Before we do, what were those Glencore headlines crossing the tape late yesterday?

BE11:37am

Royalties business spinoff thing.

NH11:37am

Oh yes

11:37 am
NH11:37am

reheated story

NH11:37am

11:37 am
NH11:38am

https://www.ft.com...-b9c7-15af748b60d0

NH11:38am

interesting idea though

NH11:38am

RBC - which is effectively Glencore's house broker these days not one of the big US banks - has some commentary on the idea

11:38 am
NH11:38am

and Glencore's lowly valuation

NH11:38am

if the punters want it

BE11:39am

Okay.

11:39 am
NH11:39am

Our view: We continue to see Glencore's differentiated approach towards growth and portfolio optimisation as being a key differentiator for long-term value creation, in a sector where we see compelling medium-term opportunities, but a lack of proactive investment. As there are limited details on this new royalty vehicle it is still too early to be able to ascribe any specific value, but in our view this new vehicle should drive value both in terms of medium-term growth opportunities but also in regards to valuation uplift.

- From a growth perspective, the JV will provide Glencore with a captive offtake base for it to grow its metals trading volumes via royalty financing.

- The new streams will provide incremental cash flow and earnings that should reduce the overall volatility of the industrial metals portfolio. This would in theory reduce the cost of capital for the group overall.

- Existing streams, from the current asset base, will provide a read-through value on assets that may be undervalued within the wider Glencore portfolio, once the vehicle is listed (if it does eventually get listed).

Glencore has created similar strategies in zinc (Trevali), energy infrastructure (HNA) and Glenagri (Canadian Pension Funds) which will provide growth with shared capital expense and across a diversified base of areas.

NH11:39am

n the near-term, we highlight in the chart below that Glencore's spot 2018e EV/EBITDA multiple has not revalued with the sector since August. This in our view is because the market is unwilling to price thermal coal at the current $95/t Newcastle level. We agree that coal prices are likely to drift with the eventual end to strikes in the Bowen Basin and with Chinese Qinhuangdao prices now rolling over. But the market, especially for higher quality coal remains tight and India continues to soak up significant imports. With ~130mt of annual production, this level of coal prices would drive c. $5-5.5bn of EBITDA and significantly bolster Glencore's net debt position. Although we continue to expect Glencore to make acquisitions over the coming 12 months, at the current point, we would have Glencore reach a net cash position at the end of 2018e.

NH11:40am

Coal prices at nearly $100

11:39 am
BE11:40am

BE11:41am

Hard to forget when Glencore's differentiated approach to growth and portfolio optimisation involved an emergency rights issue shortly after a cash return. But, hey, whatever. I'm sure the same management doesn't get things wrong twice.

NH11:41am

Here's BMO on coal, in a note that was pubbed today.

11:41 am
NH11:41am

The strength in the Asian industrial cycle is providing robust fundamental support for the thermal coal market, a trend which we see as continuing for 2018. Certainly, all the long-term structural challenges remain, but just two years after being written off completely, global thermal coal trade is booming. Seaborne volumes are now running at record levels, and high-single-digit coal-fired generation growth in Asia has necessitated a supply response from marginal producers, most notably the US. As we enter the period of seasonal supply disruptions, and with Indian stocks very low, such marginal tonnes will still be needed to balance the market.

NH11:42am

Good for Glencore, Peabody (which is back from chapter 11)

BE11:42am

Oh, and just to round up the sector, Credit Suisse has a rejig of its mining bear case out today.

11:42 am

It looks like this.

BE11:42am

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Quite a lot of stuff in there about acquisition risk for Glencore and Rio Tinto in particular.

BE11:43am

Which seems to be a gathering theme. Barclays was saying the same yesterday.

NH11:43am

go on

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Let me quote a bit.

BE11:44am

As debt and capex become less focus points for investors and the sector, it is reflected in not only rising price to book ratios but also increasing book values as equity ratios are restored (or in Rio Tinto's case we forecast book value to fall as the company returns capital via buybacks and dividends to shareholders).
One of the best examples is Anglo American which has restored its book value from $16.6bn at Dec-2015 to what we expect will be $22.9bn by the end of 2018 or a ~38% increase (and a 33% increase by Dec-2017). This has seen Anglo’s equity ratio (equity as portion of total capital (equity plus debt)) increase from 56% to 84%.

NH11:44am

(Can I get a copy of this note please)

11:44 am
BE11:45am

(Sure.)

BE11:45am

In terms of Rio specifically ..........

BE11:45am

Blue sky valuation: 4,800GBp: +30%: Our Blue Sky valuation: reflects the scenario that iron ore prices remain elevated through 2018 (at above $90/tonne), Chinese intervenes in the aluminium market causing a 30% increase in prices for 12 months, and $3bn of non-core assets are sold with 100% of proceeds passed to shareholders (via buybacks / dividends).
■ What are the risks? Chinese winter steel production reductions make us more iron ore price cautious but unless iron ore falls below say $53/t, we think the market sees more safety in buying Rio when iron ore is priced at these levels. We remain positive on aluminium prices on (20%+ of EBITDA and significantly FCF positive) as inventory and production declines, capacity is reduced and demand continues to grow. We do not see capex or acquisitions as significant investment risks - in fact increasing either on the right opportunity is a potential positive.

11:45 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,505, down 87 (-2.42%), High: 3,548, Low: 3,481, Volume: 1.54m

NH11:50am

11:50 am
NH11:50am

The magic of two = a new renaissance? Should Mick Davis become chairman, could he (working with relatively new but already respected CEO JS Jacques) enable a similar renaissance at Rio Tinto? We do think that the industry is somewhat lacking both mandate and confidence at the moment after a series of missteps throughout and perhaps because of the China super-cycle (again, Case Studies in Value Destruction). As such, we observe limited appetite & willingness to deploy capital both organically and inorganically. But perhaps, this group-think speaks to opportunity? Mr. Davis grew Xstrata quickly through aggressive M&A, helped by the China super-cycle.

The G word: Glencore: Investors will also remember that RIO rejected a merger approach from Glencore in mid-2014. Given Mr. Davis’s previous working relationship with Glencore (GLEN was a 34% shareholder of Xstrata), we think that should Mick Davis become Chairman at RIO, investors are likely to at least ask – as the Sky News article implies – if this sets the scene for (at minimum) another discussion. We are Buyers of RIO on strong cash flow and capital return potential. PO GBp4500 / A$78.

12:01 pm
NH12:02pm

Farmers are stepping up pressure on the government to address a shortage of migrant workers that is forcing many to leave fruit and vegetables to rot this autumn. Cornwall Council said last week that its farmers were unable to cope with harvesting fully this year.

Adam Paynter, council leader, said the horticulture industry was “already feeling the pinch with some of our crops rotting in the fields following a sharp fall in the number of EU workers”.

Riviera Produce, a regional grower based in Hayle, said the industry would not survive without access to migrant labour. David Simmons, managing director of the farm which dates back to 1870, said: “If we put strict limits on eastern European migrant labour or devise alternative immigration policies that limit so-called ‘low-skilled’ labour, the Cornish horticultural industry is finished.”

BE12:04pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Legal completions reached 2,935 (UBSe 2,934) and private ASP at £391k leading to revenue growth of +6-7% missing guidance/UBSe of +10% y/y for FY17. EBIT margins
are expected at the top end of the 18-20% range (UBSe 20%), implying a c5% miss to our forecasts. ROCE is expected to approach 30% (in line).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: Underlying sales rates averaged 0.77 (-5% y/y) reflecting higher ASP's and a softer Central London market. Forward sales for FY18 completions are up 18% at £265m.
Net cash at FY17 was £33m.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Crest remains confident it will meet its mid-term targets of £1.4bn sales by FY19E.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: While the miss on FY17 results might lead to some weakness in the shares, we believe the recent stock underperformance vs the sector had already discounted this possibility in light of the soft H117. The shares currently trade on 6.5x P/E'18E.

Nov. 15 (Financial Review) -- Activist investor Elliott
was tight-lipped about the future of its investment in BHP
Billiton on Wednesday, after the hedge fund's latest filing in
the US indicated it had changed its exposure to the
Melbourne-based miner.
Documents filed with the US Securities Exchange Commission
(SEC) on Wednesday morning listed 83 companies to which Elliott
had an exposure, but unlike recent filings, the documents
contained no reference to BHP.
Elliott's past five quarterly disclosures to the SEC had
all listed BHP as a holding, with the hedge fund owning BHP
through American depositary receipts linked to the miner's
London listed stock.
The last time BHP was not mentioned in one of Elliott's
"13F" documents was in May 2016; almost a year before the hedge
fund started its very public campaign for change at BHP.

NH12:08pm

Our view: We remain concerned around the potential for financial liabilities arising from Samarco over the coming 10 days as ‎the revised Brazilian Public civil suit deadline approaches on November 16. The lawsuits from the Federal Government and the Federal Prosecution Office amount to a total BRL 177.2bn (BHP 50% liable). We would expect that a settlement even close to the full amount would be highly unlikely. This said, there is potential that BHP’s liabilities could increase beyond the current Renova liabilities. The table below provides some benchmarking on the potential impact to equity. We leave our forecasts unchanged which includes the existing Renova funding but does not include any additional punitive civil claim.

12:08 pm
NH12:08pm

In recent separate meetings with both Andrew Mackenzie, CEO and Fabio Schvartsman, CEO of Samarco JV partner Vale, the topic of the Samarco structure was discussed and in our view, once the civil suit is settled we would expect Vale to take control of the asset, likely with some form of reduced profit share once, and if, the asset is ever restarted. We also note the recent challenges that Vale is facing with tailings dam permits for its Itabiritos operations.

This morning BHP has released a media statement outlining the contributions and progress made via the Renova Foundation for the ‎reconstruction and compensation for those affected by the 2015 Fundao tailings dam disaster. Highlights include: Environmental programs are proceeding well with water quality levels in the Rio Doce returned to pre-dam failure levels. Resettlement and compensation programs have also made progress "but this is slower than we would have liked in some areas". BHP has committed $500m to date and an additional $550m will be made available from 2018. Approximately 20,000 people are economically being supported and 230,000 people of 400,000 impacted have settled claims for the period when water supplies were impacted. Renova is undergoing a 10 year program to restore 5000 springs (500 underway) and has upgraded 14 water treatment plants along Rio Doce. Renova has completed 2184 hectares of a total 40,000 pledged.
